lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six actions (study, draw, talk, drink, eat, write) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Show flashcards or SB pictures (study, draw, write, etc.). Say the word, and students act it out or point to the matching picture.
stretchStrategies: Make it a chain! Students ask, “What are you doing?” and respond using “I’m…” – then choose another classmate to ask the same question. The chain continues until everyone has spoken. Challenge: Use 3 different verbs in a row without repeating.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about actions using “What are you doing?” / “What’s he/she doing?” and respond with “I’m... / He’s... / She’s...”.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Ask: “What are you doing?” Model: “I’m drawing.” Then mime an action. Students guess and respond: “You’re writing!”
stretchStrategies: Make it a chain! Students ask, “What are you doing?” and respond using “I’m…” – then choose another classmate to ask the same question. The chain continues until everyone has spoken. Challenge: Use 3 different verbs in a row without repeating.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “What are you doing?” / “What’s he/she doing?” / “I’m ___.” / “He’s/She’s ___.” to talk about actions.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) On board: “What is he doing?” / “He’s ___.” Students practise with images, realia, or SB actions.

items: The -ing is often forgotten. Vietnamese does not have different forms of the same verb. I like eat rice.

Systematic kinds of silent letters, such as 'magic e' in late or mote, or silent gh in thought and bought, are entirely alien to Vietnamese. They are often acquired as sight words first; the teacher can explain at higher levels.

Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
